questiontext.text:
Q3 — Laplace Transform: RL Step-Response Circuit (13 pts)

A series RL circuit consists of a resistor \(R = {@R@}\;\Omega\) and an inductor \(L = {@L@}\;\text{H}\) connected in series. At \(t = 0\), a DC voltage source \(V_s = {@Vs@}\;\text{V}\) is applied as a step input \(V_s \cdot u(t)\). Assume zero initial conditions (no current flowing before \(t=0\)).

[INSERT DIAGRAM: diagrams/q3/q3_v1_rl_step.svg]

Part A (2 pts) — S-Domain Component Model (MCQ)

When transforming the circuit to the s-domain with zero initial conditions, how is the inductor \(L\) modeled?

Select the correct s-domain impedance of the inductor:

[[input:ansA]] [[validation:ansA]]

Options:

  • (a) \(sL\)
  • (b) \(\dfrac{1}{sL}\)
  • (c) \(\dfrac{L}{s}\)
  • (d) \(s^2 L\)

Enter the letter of your choice: a, b, c, or d.

[[feedback:prtA]]

Part B (4 pts) — Transfer Function

Using the s-domain model, the current in the circuit is \(I(s)\) and the input voltage transform is \(V(s)\).

Determine the transfer function \(H(s) = \dfrac{I(s)}{V(s)}\).

Express your answer as a rational function of \(s\). Use the variable s.

For example, if your answer were \(\dfrac{3}{s+5}\), type 3/(s+5).

\(H(s) = \) [[input:ansB]] [[validation:ansB]]

[[feedback:prtB]]

Part C (4 pts) — Time Constant

Compute the time constant \(\tau\) of this RL circuit.

Give your answer in seconds as a decimal number (e.g., 0.0005).

\(\tau = \) [[input:ansC]] seconds [[validation:ansC]]

[[feedback:prtC]]

Part D (3 pts) — Initial/Final Value Check & Physical Meaning (Essay)

Using the Initial Value Theorem and the Final Value Theorem, verify the behaviour of the current \(i(t)\):

  • Show that \(i(0^+) = 0\) using the Initial Value Theorem on \(I(s)\).
  • Show that \(i(\infty) = V_s/R = {@Vs/R@}\;\text{A}\) using the Final Value Theorem.
  • Explain the physical meaning of the time constant \(\tau = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\) in this circuit. What fraction of the final current is reached at \(t = \tau\)?

Write your answer below:

generalfeedback.text:
Solution — Variant 1 (RL Step Response)

Part A: With zero initial conditions, an inductor \(L\) in the s-domain is represented by impedance \(Z_L = sL\). Answer: (a).

Part B: KVL in s-domain: \(V(s) = I(s)(R + sL)\), so \[H(s) = \frac{I(s)}{V(s)} = \frac{1}{R + sL} = \frac{1}{{@R@} + s \cdot {@L@}}\]

Part C: The time constant is \(\tau = L/R = {@L@}/{@R@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

Part D:

  • Initial Value Theorem: \(\lim_{s\to\infty} s \cdot I(s) = \lim_{s\to\infty} \frac{s \cdot V_s/s}{R+sL} = \lim_{s\to\infty} \frac{V_s}{R+sL} = 0\). So \(i(0^+)=0\). The inductor initially opposes any change in current.
  • Final Value Theorem: \(\lim_{s\to 0} s \cdot I(s) = \lim_{s\to 0} \frac{V_s}{R+sL} = V_s/R = {@Vs/R@}\;\text{A}\). At steady state, the inductor acts as a short circuit.
  • The time constant \(\tau = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\) is the time it takes for the current to reach approximately \(63.2\%\) of its final value. After \(5\tau\), the current is within \(1\%\) of its final value.

questionnote.text: V1 RL Step: Vs={@Vs@}, R={@R@}, L={@L@}, tau={@tau@}, H(s)={@Hs@}

questiondescription.text: Laplace Transform — RL step response. Series RL driven by Vs*u(t). 13 pts total.

node.description: Check MCQ answer for Part A

truefeedback.text: Correct! An inductor with zero initial conditions is modeled as impedance \(sL\) in the s-domain.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. With zero initial conditions, the inductor \(L\) is modeled in the s-domain by its impedance \(Z_L = sL\). The correct answer is (a).
Incorrect. By KVL in the s-domain: \(V(s) = I(s)(R + sL)\), so \(H(s) = \dfrac{I(s)}{V(s)} = \dfrac{1}{R+sL} = {@correctB@}\).
Incorrect. For an RL circuit, the time constant is \(\tau = L/R = {@L@}/{@R@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

questiontext.text:
Q3 — Laplace Transform: RC Step-Response Circuit (13 pts)

A series RC circuit consists of a resistor \(R = {@R@}\;\Omega\) and a capacitor \(C = {@C@}\;\text{F}\) connected in series. At \(t = 0\), a DC voltage source \(V_s = {@Vs@}\;\text{V}\) is applied as a step input \(V_s \cdot u(t)\). Assume zero initial conditions (capacitor initially uncharged).

[INSERT DIAGRAM: diagrams/q3/q3_v2_rc_step.svg]

Part A (2 pts) — S-Domain Component Model (MCQ)

When transforming the circuit to the s-domain with zero initial conditions, how is the capacitor \(C\) modeled?

Select the correct s-domain impedance of the capacitor:

[[input:ansA]] [[validation:ansA]]

Options:

  • (a) \(sC\)
  • (b) \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\)
  • (c) \(\dfrac{C}{s}\)
  • (d) \(\dfrac{s}{C}\)

Enter the letter of your choice: a, b, c, or d.

[[feedback:prtA]]

Part B (4 pts) — Transfer Function

Determine the transfer function relating the voltage across the capacitor to the input voltage:

\[H(s) = \frac{V_C(s)}{V_s(s)}\]

Express your answer as a rational function of \(s\). Use the variable s.

For example, if your answer were \(\dfrac{1}{1+0.5 s}\), type 1/(1+0.5*s).

\(H(s) = \) [[input:ansB]] [[validation:ansB]]

[[feedback:prtB]]

Part C (4 pts) — Time Constant

Compute the time constant \(\tau\) of this RC circuit.

Give your answer in seconds as a decimal number (e.g., 0.047).

\(\tau = \) [[input:ansC]] seconds [[validation:ansC]]

[[feedback:prtC]]

Part D (3 pts) — Physical Meaning of Time Constant (Essay)

Answer the following:

  • Use the Initial Value Theorem to find \(v_C(0^+)\).
  • Use the Final Value Theorem to find \(v_C(\infty)\).
  • Explain the physical meaning of the time constant \(\tau = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\) in this circuit. At \(t = \tau\), what percentage of the final voltage has the capacitor reached?

Write your answer below:

generalfeedback.text:
Solution — Variant 2 (RC Step Response)

Part A: With zero initial conditions, a capacitor \(C\) in the s-domain is represented by impedance \(Z_C = \dfrac{1}{sC}\). Answer: (b).

Part B: By voltage divider: \[H(s) = \frac{V_C(s)}{V_s(s)} = \frac{1/(sC)}{R + 1/(sC)} = \frac{1}{1 + sRC} = {@correctB@}\]

Part C: The time constant is \(\tau = RC = {@R@} \times {@C@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

Part D:

  • Initial Value Theorem: \(v_C(0^+) = \lim_{s\to\infty} s \cdot V_C(s) = \lim_{s\to\infty} \frac{s \cdot V_s/s}{1+sRC} = \lim_{s\to\infty} \frac{V_s}{1+sRC} = 0\). The capacitor voltage starts at zero.
  • Final Value Theorem: \(v_C(\infty) = \lim_{s\to 0} s \cdot V_C(s) = \lim_{s\to 0} \frac{V_s}{1+sRC} = V_s = {@Vs@}\;\text{V}\). The capacitor charges fully to the source voltage.
  • The time constant \(\tau = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\) represents the time at which the capacitor reaches approximately \(63.2\%\) of its final voltage (\(1 - e^{-1} \approx 0.632\)). After \(5\tau\), the capacitor is within \(1\%\) of its final value.

questionnote.text: V2 RC Step: Vs={@Vs@}, R={@R@}, C={@C@}, tau={@tau@}, H(s)={@correctB@}

questiondescription.text: Laplace Transform — RC step response. Series RC driven by Vs*u(t). 13 pts total.

node.description: Check MCQ answer for Part A

truefeedback.text: Correct! A capacitor with zero initial conditions is modeled as impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\) in the s-domain.

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. With zero initial conditions, the capacitor \(C\) is modeled in the s-domain by its impedance \(Z_C = \dfrac{1}{sC}\). The correct answer is (b).
Incorrect. Using voltage divider in the s-domain: \(H(s) = \dfrac{1/(sC)}{R+1/(sC)} = \dfrac{1}{1+sRC} = {@correctB@}\).
Incorrect. For an RC circuit, the time constant is \(\tau = RC = {@R@} \times {@C@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

questiontext.text:
Q3 — Laplace Transform: RL Natural Response Circuit (13 pts)

An inductor \(L = {@L@}\;\text{H}\) carries an initial current \(I_0 = {@I0@}\;\text{A}\) at \(t = 0\). At \(t = 0\), the source is removed and the inductor is connected across a resistor \(R = {@R@}\;\Omega\). There is no external source — this is a natural (source-free) response.

[INSERT DIAGRAM: diagrams/q3/q3_v3_rl_natural.svg]

Part A (2 pts) — S-Domain Component Model (MCQ)

In the s-domain, how is an inductor \(L\) with a nonzero initial current \(I_0\) modeled?

Select the correct s-domain model:

[[input:ansA]] [[validation:ansA]]

Options:

  • (a) Impedance \(sL\) only (no initial condition source)
  • (b) Impedance \(sL\) in series with a voltage source \(LI_0\) (representing the initial condition)
  • (c) Impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sL}\) in parallel with a current source \(I_0/s\)
  • (d) Impedance \(sL\) in series with a voltage source \(I_0/s\)

Enter the letter of your choice: a, b, c, or d.

[[feedback:prtA]]

Part B (4 pts) — S-Domain Current Expression

Using the s-domain circuit model with the initial condition, find the expression for \(I(s)\), the Laplace transform of the inductor current \(i(t)\).

Express your answer as a function of \(s\). Use the variable s.

For example, if your answer were \(\dfrac{2}{s+100}\), type 2/(s+100).

\(I(s) = \) [[input:ansB]] [[validation:ansB]]

[[feedback:prtB]]

Part C (4 pts) — Time Constant

Compute the time constant \(\tau\) of this RL natural response.

Give your answer in seconds as a decimal number (e.g., 0.0002).

\(\tau = \) [[input:ansC]] seconds [[validation:ansC]]

[[feedback:prtC]]

Part D (3 pts) — Energy Dissipation (Essay)

Answer the following:

  • Use the Initial Value Theorem to verify that \(i(0^+) = I_0 = {@I0@}\;\text{A}\).
  • Use the Final Value Theorem to verify that \(i(\infty) = 0\).
  • The initial energy stored in the inductor is \(W_0 = \frac{1}{2}LI_0^2 = {@W0@}\;\text{J}\). Where does this energy go as \(t \to \infty\)? Explain the physical process.

Write your answer below:

generalfeedback.text:
Solution — Variant 3 (RL Natural Response)

Part A: An inductor with initial current \(I_0\) is modeled in the s-domain as impedance \(sL\) in series with a voltage source \(LI_0\) (with polarity such that it drives current in the direction of \(I_0\)). This arises from \(\mathcal{L}\{L\,di/dt\} = sL \cdot I(s) - LI_0\). Answer: (b).

Part B: KVL around the loop: \(sL \cdot I(s) - LI_0 + R \cdot I(s) = 0\), so: \[I(s) = \frac{LI_0}{sL + R} = \frac{I_0}{s + R/L} = {@correctB@}\]

Part C: The time constant is \(\tau = L/R = {@L@}/{@R@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

Part D:

  • Initial Value Theorem: \(\lim_{s\to\infty} s \cdot I(s) = \lim_{s\to\infty} \frac{s \cdot I_0}{s + R/L} = I_0 = {@I0@}\;\text{A}\). Confirmed.
  • Final Value Theorem: \(\lim_{s\to 0} s \cdot I(s) = \lim_{s\to 0} \frac{s \cdot I_0}{s + R/L} = 0\). The current decays to zero.
  • The initial energy \(W_0 = \frac{1}{2}({@L@})({@I0@})^2 = {@W0@}\;\text{J}\) is entirely dissipated as heat in the resistor \(R\). As the current decays exponentially, the instantaneous power \(p(t) = i^2(t)R\) is dissipated in the resistor, and integrating over all time gives \(\int_0^\infty i^2 R\,dt = W_0\).

questionnote.text: V3 RL Natural: I0={@I0@}, R={@R@}, L={@L@}, tau={@tau@}, I(s)={@correctB@}, W0={@W0@}

questiondescription.text: Laplace Transform — RL natural response. Inductor with initial current, resistor. 13 pts total.

node.description: Check MCQ answer for Part A

truefeedback.text: Correct! An inductor with initial current \(I_0\) is modeled as impedance \(sL\) in series with a voltage source \(LI_0\).

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. The s-domain model of an inductor with initial current \(I_0\) includes impedance \(sL\) in series with a voltage source \(LI_0\). This comes from \(\mathcal{L}\{L\,di/dt\} = sL \cdot I(s) - LI_0\). The correct answer is (b).
Incorrect. From KVL: \(sL \cdot I(s) - LI_0 + R \cdot I(s) = 0\), giving \(I(s) = \dfrac{LI_0}{sL+R} = \dfrac{I_0}{s+R/L} = {@correctB@}\).
Incorrect. For an RL circuit, the time constant is \(\tau = L/R = {@L@}/{@R@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

questiontext.text:
Q3 — Laplace Transform: RC Natural Response Circuit (13 pts)

A capacitor \(C = {@C@}\;\text{F}\) is initially charged to a voltage \(V_0 = {@V0@}\;\text{V}\). At \(t = 0\), the capacitor is connected across a resistor \(R = {@R@}\;\Omega\). There is no external source — this is a natural (source-free) response.

[INSERT DIAGRAM: diagrams/q3/q3_v4_rc_natural.svg]

Part A (2 pts) — S-Domain Component Model (MCQ)

In the s-domain, how is a capacitor \(C\) with an initial voltage \(V_0\) modeled?

Select the correct s-domain model:

[[input:ansA]] [[validation:ansA]]

Options:

  • (a) Impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\) only (no initial condition source)
  • (b) Impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\) in series with a voltage source \(\dfrac{V_0}{s}\) (representing the initial condition)
  • (c) Impedance \(sC\) in series with a voltage source \(V_0 \cdot s\)
  • (d) Impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\) in parallel with a current source \(\dfrac{V_0}{R}\)

Enter the letter of your choice: a, b, c, or d.

[[feedback:prtA]]

Part B (4 pts) — S-Domain Voltage Expression

Using the s-domain circuit model with the initial condition, find the expression for \(V_C(s)\), the Laplace transform of the capacitor voltage \(v_C(t)\).

Express your answer as a function of \(s\). Use the variable s.

For example, if your answer were \(\dfrac{10}{s+50}\), type 10/(s+50).

\(V_C(s) = \) [[input:ansB]] [[validation:ansB]]

[[feedback:prtB]]

Part C (4 pts) — Time Constant

Compute the time constant \(\tau\) of this RC natural response.

Give your answer in seconds as a decimal number (e.g., 0.047).

\(\tau = \) [[input:ansC]] seconds [[validation:ansC]]

[[feedback:prtC]]

Part D (3 pts) — Initial/Final Value Check & Energy Dissipation (Essay)

Answer the following:

  • Use the Initial Value Theorem to verify that \(v_C(0^+) = V_0 = {@V0@}\;\text{V}\).
  • Use the Final Value Theorem to verify that \(v_C(\infty) = 0\).
  • The initial energy stored in the capacitor is \(W_0 = \frac{1}{2}CV_0^2 = {@W0@}\;\text{J}\). Explain where this energy goes as \(t \to \infty\) and describe the physical process of energy dissipation.

Write your answer below:

generalfeedback.text:
Solution — Variant 4 (RC Natural Response)

Part A: A capacitor with initial voltage \(V_0\) is modeled in the s-domain as impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\) in series with a voltage source \(\dfrac{V_0}{s}\). This comes from the Laplace transform of the capacitor constitutive relation: \(V_C(s) = \dfrac{1}{sC}I(s) + \dfrac{V_0}{s}\). Answer: (b).

Part B: The current flowing through the resistor is \(I(s)\), and KVL gives: \[\frac{V_0}{s} + \frac{1}{sC}I(s) = R \cdot I(s) \quad \Rightarrow \quad \text{(or using node voltage directly)}\] Actually, the capacitor voltage satisfies \(V_C(s) = \dfrac{V_0}{s + 1/(RC)}\) because the discharge equation transforms to: \[RC \cdot sV_C(s) - RC \cdot V_0 + V_C(s) = 0 \implies V_C(s)(sRC+1) = RCV_0 \implies V_C(s) = \frac{V_0}{s+1/(RC)} = {@correctB@}\]

Part C: The time constant is \(\tau = RC = {@R@} \times {@C@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

Part D:

  • Initial Value Theorem: \(\lim_{s\to\infty} s \cdot V_C(s) = \lim_{s\to\infty} \frac{s \cdot V_0}{s + 1/(RC)} = V_0 = {@V0@}\;\text{V}\). Confirmed.
  • Final Value Theorem: \(\lim_{s\to 0} s \cdot V_C(s) = \lim_{s\to 0} \frac{s \cdot V_0}{s + 1/(RC)} = 0\). The voltage decays to zero.
  • The initial energy \(W_0 = \frac{1}{2}({@C@})({@V0@})^2 = {@W0@}\;\text{J}\) is entirely dissipated as heat in the resistor \(R\). As the capacitor discharges, current flows through \(R\), and the power \(p(t) = v_C^2(t)/R\) is converted to thermal energy. The total energy dissipated is \(\int_0^\infty v_C^2/R\,dt = W_0\).

questionnote.text: V4 RC Natural: V0={@V0@}, R={@R@}, C={@C@}, tau={@tau@}, Vc(s)={@correctB@}, W0={@W0@}

questiondescription.text: Laplace Transform — RC natural response. Capacitor with initial voltage, resistor. 13 pts total.

node.description: Check MCQ answer for Part A

truefeedback.text: Correct! A capacitor with initial voltage \(V_0\) is modeled as impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\) in series with a voltage source \(\dfrac{V_0}{s}\).

falsefeedback.text: Incorrect. The s-domain model of a capacitor with initial voltage \(V_0\) includes impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\) in series with a voltage source \(\dfrac{V_0}{s}\). This arises from \(V_C(s) = \dfrac{1}{sC}I(s) + \dfrac{V_0}{s}\). The correct answer is (b).
Incorrect. The RC discharge transforms to \(V_C(s)(sRC+1) = RCV_0\), giving \(V_C(s) = \dfrac{V_0}{s+1/(RC)} = {@correctB@}\).
Incorrect. For an RC circuit, the time constant is \(\tau = RC = {@R@} \times {@C@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).
